tossups.question: Diego Fasolis and Fabio Ceresa have collaborated to produce several of this composer's operas; most recently, a pastoral opera in which this composer cast his longtime collaborator Anna Girò. Though this composer claimed to have written 94 operas, less than half of them survive, with many partly reconstructed  thanks to Alberto Gentili's discovery of his manuscripts. Like Handel, this composer of Dorilla in Tempe wrote a dramma per musica adaptation of Ariosto's epic poem (*) Orlando Furioso. The librettist Anna Bon was one of this composer's orphaned pupils at the Ospedale della Pietà ("ohs-peh-DAH-lay del-lah pee-eh-TAH"). He is best-known today for a set of orchestral pieces which depict buzzing flies, barking dogs, and thunderstorms, each accompanied by a sonnet. For 10 points, name this "Red Priest" who composed The Four Seasons.
tossups.answer: Antonio Vivaldi

tossups.question: A form of this practice with seven "witnesses", including sky, earth, and salt, was said to cure disease by the Elcesaites ("el-KEZ-ay-ites"). This practice is done weekly before a ritual meal for the dead by the Mandaeans ("man-DAY-uns"). In the Greek Orthodox church, this practice is accompanied by the statement "Let all adverse powers be crushed beneath the signing". The Catholic Church may use a conditional form of this practice, as it can be done only (*) once due to making an indelible seal; they also recognize exceptional forms "of desire" and "of blood". Mormons have a living proxy undergo this practice on behalf of a dead person. In some sects, only those past the age of accountability can undergo this practice, its believer's form, but most require that it be done to infants. For 10 points, people become Christians through what sacrament using water?
tossups.answer: baptism [accept word forms such as baptizing]

tossups.question: In a story from this collection, a "girl of nineteen" sings "I'm a...naughty girl / You needn't sham / You know I am" to entertain residents of The Madam's establishment. Another story from this collection ends as Joe's eyes fill with tears when he hears the song "I Dreamt that I Dwelt". In a third of its stories, a "stirring patriotic recitation" concludes a concert attended by numerous artistes ("ar-TEESTS"), who disappoint the title character by paying nothing to her piano-playing (*) daughter. In yet another story from this collection, Kate Morkan hosts a party where she praises the voice of the tenor Bartell d'Arcy; Bartell then sings "The Lass of Aughrim," bringing about an intimate moment between Gretta and Gabriel Conroy. The story "The Dead" is from, for 10 points, what James Joyce collection?
tossups.answer: Dubliners (The first three clues are from "The Boarding-House," "Clay," and "A Mother" respectively.)
tossups.metadata: The first three clues are from "The Boarding-House," "Clay," and "A Mother" respectively.

tossups.question: In bioinformatics, methods for performing this task include the FLAME algorithm and the program CD-HIT. An algorithm called OPTICS performs a neighborhood query to estimate the step parameter epsilon, thus improving an algorithm for this task called DBSCAN. The software package Scikit uses a common algorithm for this task that is based on constructing and updating tessellations of Voronoi cells; that is (*) Lloyd's algorithm. A set of models for this task involves minimizing the total squared distance of a group of points to the nearest assigned centroid. The k-means algorithm performs this unsupervised learning task, which is an alternative to the related task of classification. For 10 points, what task involves sorting data into namesake groups based on similarities?
tossups.answer: clustering [accept cluster analysis]

tossups.question: Matthias de Groof used paintings by TKM to analyze this leader's portrayals in art. This leader rebuked the "colonial trinity" in a speech at the Palais de la Nation ("pah-LEE de la nah-SYON") which he was invited to give by his protégé, Joseph Kasongo. This leader brought such politicians as Albert Kalonji, the later leader of South Kasai, to prominence by founding a political party called the MNC. Soon after concluding independence talks with King (*) Baudouin ("bow-DWAHN"), this leader was forced to take refuge in Stanleyville when he was dismissed by Joseph Kasa-Vubu. He appealed to Dag Hammarskjöld ("HAH-mar-shold") to end the Katanga secession crisis, but was assassinated in 1961 by allies of Mobutu Sese-Seko before it ended. For 10 points, name this first prime minister of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
tossups.answer: Patrice Émery Lumumba

tossups.question: This painting is partly divided by a diagonal orange line which cuts through the bottom left of a carafe of water. As noted in the Art Institute of Chicago's description of this painting, an L-shaped section was cut from its bottom and right, but later re-added. Its artist (emphasize) borrowed from Edouard Manet by abstractly reflecting the eerie light of gas and electric lamps in the background mirrors, which a woman uses to check her hair. This painting's asymmetric composition is enhanced by the diagonal (*) wooden balustrade on its left. It features the dancer La Goulue ("goo-LOO"), the red-haired Jane Avril ("ah-VREEL") sitting with three men in top hats at a table, and May Milton, whose pale-green makeup-covered face dominates the right. For 10 points, name this Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec ("on-REE duh too-LOOZ-low-TREK") painting of the title Parisian cabaret.
tossups.answer: At the Moulin Rouge [or Au Moulin Rouge; prompt on Moulin Rouge]
tossups.answer_formatted: At the Moulin Rouge [or Au Moulin Rouge; prompt on Moulin Rouge]

tossups.question: In 2018, a corruption scandal began in this country when the U.S. Treasury exposed money laundering on behalf of North Korea by the ABLV bank. This country's ZZS party, the first Green Party in the world to produce a Prime Minister, was excluded from the New Unity-led coalition government formed in 2019. This country is the (emphasize) second-most recent adopter of the Euro, having done so in 2014. This non-Polish country's parliament is called the (*) Saiema ("SIGH-mah"). In April 2020 the U.S. imposed Magnitsky Act sanctions on the mayor of its major port of Ventspils. Smugglers in this country often travel down its Daugava ("dow-GAH-vah") river, which flows into its capital city, which lies on a namesake gulf in the Baltic Sea. Livonia is a region of, for 10 points, what country whose capital is Riga?
tossups.answer: Latvia [or Republic of Latvia; or Latvijas Republika]

tossups.question: Margery Michelmore's unmailed postcard sparked student riots against this organization at the University of Ibadan. Louisiana representative Otto Passman was labeled “Otto the Terrible” for calling for massive spending cuts for this organization. This organization's creation was inspired by a student petition written after its creator gave an impromptu 1960 speech at the University of Michigan. Richard Nixon called this program "a haven for (*) draft-dodgers" but, as president, he would merge it with ACTION. This program was inspired by James H. Robinson's Operation Crossroads Africa, and its founder picked his brother-in-law Sargent Shriver to be its first director. For 10 points, name this volunteer program created by John F. Kennedy, which provides social and economic assistance to various countries.
tossups.answer: Peace Corps

tossups.question: This poet's lines are paired with explanations of Radha Soami doctrine in a translation of an edition of this poet's best-known collection which adds over 500 extra verses, carried out by M.G. Gupta. Original lines by this poet were loosely adapted into such lines as "What you seek is seeking you" and "Out beyond ideas of rightdoing and wrongdoing, there is a field". A command to listen to complaints of "separation" from a (*) reed flute opens the best-known collection by this poet, who is often considered the most widely read poet in the U.S. thanks to popular, free verse translations by Coleman Barks. The tomb of this disciple of Shams of Tabriz is a shrine for the Mevlevi order, which is named after him. The Masnavi or Spiritual Couplets are by, for 10 points, what Sufi who wrote in Persian?
tossups.answer: Jalāl ad-Dīn Muhammad Rūmī [or Jalāl ad-Dīn Muhammad Balkhī; accept Mawlana; accept Mevlev before "Mevlevi"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Jalāl ad-Dīn Muhammad Rūmī [or Jalāl ad-Dīn Muhammad Balkhī; accept Mawlana; accept Mevlev before "Mevlevi]

tossups.question: A class of reactions involving these elements was found in 2015 to produce the first known non-laser-induced Coulomb explosion. Jean-Marie Lehn shared part of the 1987 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for complexing one of these elements within the compound [2.2.2]cryptand. The chelate and macrocyclic effects allow these elements to favorably coordinate to many oxygen atoms in the center of a crown ether. These elements dissolve in (*) ammonia to give a deep blue color caused by solvated electrons. Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff invented spectroscopy, then used it to discover two of these elements. Nearly all ionic compounds of these elements are water-soluble. For 10 points, name these elements that react violently with water because they really want to lose their single valence electron.
tossups.answer: alkali metals [or Group 1; or Group IA; prompt on metals; do not accept or prompt on "alkaline earth metals"]
tossups.answer_formatted: alkali metals [or Group 1; or Group IA; prompt on metals; do not accept or prompt on "alkaline earth metals"]

tossups.question: The first of these periods, defined by Georg Steindorff and Henri Frankfort, is generally regarded to have begun due to the "4.2 kiloyear aridification event" and the rise of hereditary nomarchs ("NO-marks"). The definitive textbook on another of these periods was written by Kenneth Kitchen, who cites details about kings named Osorkon as evidence for the Old Testament's historical accuracy. Yet another of these periods was defined by the hegemony of a group that Josephus calls "shepherd-kings," who introduced (*) chariot warfare and established their capital at Avaris. The fall of the 13th dynasty brought about the second of these periods, which was marked by Hyksos dominance. Egypt was disunited during, for 10 points, what periods named for coming in between such eras as the Middle and New Kingdoms?
tossups.answer: Intermediate Periods of Ancient Egypt [prompt on Egyptian periods or equivalents indicating periods of Egypt's history; prompt on Egyptian dynasties by saying "we want the term for the broader periods in question"; do not accept or prompt on "Egyptian kingdoms"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Intermediate Periods of Ancient Egypt [prompt on Egyptian periods or equivalents indicating periods of Egypt's history; prompt on Egyptian dynasties by saying "we want the term for the broader periods in question; do not accept or prompt on "Egyptian kingdoms"]
promptable: equivalents indicating periods of Egypt's history
Egyptian dynasties by saying "we want the term for the broader periods in question

tossups.question: This is the most common disease that can be studied with the technique of acute tryptophan depletion. A drug whose primary indication is treating this disease is also used alongside varenicline to promote smoking cessation. In modern times, the herb St. John's Wort is most often used as a supplement to treat this disease, which is the most common cause of a form of cognitive impairment called "pseudodementia". The (*) PHQ-9 is used to screen for this disease, whose diagnostic criteria are summarized in the mnemonic "SIG E CAPS." Citalopram, paroxetine, and fluoxetine are used to treat this disease by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin at the synapse. Low levels of dopamine may occur in, for 10 points, what disease characterized by persistently low mood?
tossups.answer: depression or major depressive disorder [accept MDD]

tossups.question: In Mythic Worlds, Modern Words, Joseph Campbell discusses the many similarities between this play and Finnegans Wake, such as a scene where a woman borrows a match to light a stove. This play's central family imagines that a tramp has arrived when they hear a knock, so they ready a slingshot and pile a chair and tree against a door. In its third act, a mass food poisoning makes Mr. Fitzpatrick replace the actors for his planned performance. This play begins and ends with the (*) same line, "Six o'clock and the master's not home yet," delivered by the maid Lily Sabina. In this play, the Ancient and Honorable Order of Mammals meets on the Atlantic City Boardwalk and swears in George as its president. An ice age is survived by the Antrobus family in, for 10 points, what Thornton Wilder play?
tossups.answer: The Skin of Our Teeth

tossups.question: This figure's name is given to all inhabitants of the Form and Formless Realms; one can be reborn there by cultivating virtues called this figure's namesake abodes or viharas. A gold statue of this figure is honored at Erawan Shrine in Bangkok. Upon the Buddha's enlightenment, he's persuaded to spread the Dharma by this figure's highest form, who has the epithet Sahampati ("suh-HOM-puh-tee"). This figure, known as Bonten in Japanese, rules the highest heavens above Mount Meru. This (*) originally-Hindu figure is Buddhism's highest deva but has only one major Hindu temple, located in Pushkar; in one account, that lack of worship is a curse for lying about reaching the top of a fiery linga. He rides the hamsa swan and can see in all directions with his four faces. For 10 points, Saraswati ("suh-RUSS-vuh-tee") is the consort of what creator god?
tossups.answer: Brahma [or Fantian; or Beomcheon; or Pham Thien; or tsangpa or tshangs pa; or Bya-mar; or Phra Phrom; or Preah Prom; or Brahmaya; or Bonten before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on "Brahman"; do not accept or prompt on "Benten"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Brahma [or Fantian; or Beomcheon; or Pham Thien; or tsangpa or tshangs pa; or Bya-mar; or Phra Phrom; or Preah Prom; or Brahmaya; or Bonten before mentioned; do not accept or prompt on "Brahman"; do not accept or prompt on "Benten"]

tossups.question: A book titled for these objects states "when all else fails, try bribery" as the last of eleven rules for "polishing" them, in a chapter on "how to seduce" boards. Measuring autocorrelation between features on these objects is the most common use of Moran's I statistic and semivariogram plots. The title of a statistics book by Darrel Huff is referenced by Mark Monmonier's book on "how to lie with" these objects. Their size ratios can be given by representative factions. An indicatrix named for (*) Tissot measures how these objects deviate from ideal representation. Examples of them which are shaded to give data summaries are called choropleths. A software package from ESRI called Arc generates these objects by aggregating layers of data gathered from GIS systems. For 10 points, name these objects made by cartographers.
tossups.answer: maps [accept How to Lie With Maps; accept map projections; prompt on projections, or globe projections, or Earth projections; prompt on images or charts or graphs before "cartographers"]
tossups.answer_formatted: maps [accept How to Lie With Maps; accept map projections; prompt on projections, or globe projections, or Earth projections; prompt on images or chartsprompt on graphs before "cartographers]

tossups.question: The breathing of athletes intersperses a track that uses this non-percussion instrument titled "Tour de France". Ralf Hütter played this instrument on the 1974 album Autobahn. During one of his Young People's Concerts, Leonard Bernstein performed the "Little Fugue in G" on this instrument. Producer Rachel Elkind encouraged another artist to produce an album on this instrument after hearing an arrangement of an earlier composer's Two-Part (*) Invention in F major; that album, titled Switched-On Bach, is by Wendy Carlos. Many versions of this instrument have an "arpeggiator" feature which automatically generates note patterns. The Yamaha DX7 was the first "digital" one. For 10 points, Robert Moog invented a variety of what instrument, which converts electric signals into sounds?
tossups.answer: synthesizers [prompt on Moog before "Moog"]

tossups.question: This state's longest-ruling dynasty was invested with its Kurmark ("KOOR-mark") by Sigismund at the Council of Constance. A ruler of this state grew his lands by marrying Duchess Anna, who secured a marriage for its princess Maria Eleonora against the will of Maria's brother George William. It re-acquired the Neumark ("NOY-mark") in 1454 thanks to a sale by Grand Master Ludwig von Erlichshausen ("AIR-liks-how-zen"). A later (emphasize) elector of this state invited expelled French (*) Huguenots to settle after the Edict of Fontainebleau and, thanks to his military successes in neighboring Pomerania, was called the "Great Elector". A four-horse chariot sits atop the "gate" named for this state, which was ruled by the Hohenzollerns from Potsdam. Prussia was formerly in personal union with, for 10 points, what German state which surrounds Berlin?
tossups.answer: Margraviate of Brandenburg [accept Brandenburg-Prussia; do not accept or prompt on "Prussia"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Margraviate of Brandenburg [accept Brandenburg-Prussia; do not accept or prompt on "Prussia"]

tossups.question: In phi-to-the-fourth theories, this function's density is modified by adding a quartic interaction term. This function is defined as the product of the metric and two derivatives of coordinates along a curved spacetime in a method of solving the geodesic equation. When this function's time derivative is zero, it obeys the identity "F (pause) minus x-dot times dF dx-dot (pause) equals a constant," where F is this function. By plugging this function as "F" into the equation "the time derivative of (*) dF dq-dot (pause) minus dF dq (pause) equals zero," one can derive a system's equations of motion. This function of several "generalized coordinates" may be integrated with respect to time to give the action. For 10 points, a subfield of classical mechanics is named for what function, itself named for a French scientist?
tossups.answer: Lagrangian [accept L; accept Lagrangian mechanics]

tossups.question: Edwin Curley's book on this book's "method" explains its objective with this book's concluding remark that "all things excellent are as difficult as they are rare". This book asserts "a true idea must correspond with its ideate" and "everything which exists, exists either in itself or in something else" in outlining seven guiding propositions. Contra Descartes, it argues that substances can have both "extension" and "thought". This book begins by defining that which is (*) "self-caused" as something whose "essence involves existence". It then deduces that God is a substance with infinite attributes and equates God with Nature, a pantheistic stance which got its author censured by Amsterdam's Jews. Geometric methods are applied to philosophy in, for 10 points, what treatise by Baruch Spinoza?
tossups.answer: Ethics, Demonstrated in Geometrical Order [accept answers which indicate Baruch Spinoza's Ethics]
tossups.answer_formatted: Ethics, Demonstrated in Geometrical Order [accept answers which indicate Baruch Spinoza's Ethics]
acceptable: answers which indicate Baruch Spinoza's Ethics

tossups.question: This novel's second chapter notes that, for rams to understand that they are fattened to be killed for meat, they do not need conceptions of "chance and genius". The suggestion that it is impossible to use words to describe the "life of humanity" opens this novel's second epilogue, which interprets human events as a clash of "free will" and "inevitability". As he lies wounded on a hill, a character in this novel has an out-of-body experience before he is rescued by the enemy's commander. This novel's aim of refuting the (*) Great Man theory of history is discussed in Isaiah Berlin's "The Hedgehog and the Fox". Much French dialogue is included in the Russian text of this novel, which features the characters Natasha Rostova and Andrei Bolkonsky. For 10 points, in what novel does Pierre Bezukhov articulate many views of Leo Tolstoy?
tossups.answer: War and Peace [or Voyna i mir]

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of the novel Wolf Totem navigates being relocated during this period with the help of the herder Bilgee. For 10 points each:
answers: The Cultural Revolution [or Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution or Wénhuà dàgémìng; prompt on 1960s or 1970s]
Honoré de Balzac [accept Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress]
parts: Name this historical period which provides the background for the final section of the novel To Live, whose protagonist lives with an ox as his only companion after his daughter dies in childbirth.
References to the horrors of the Cultural Revolution are interspersed throughout this novel by Gao Xingjian ("sheeng-j'yen"), whose main characters are called "You" and "I."
In a novel by Dai Sijie ("see-j'yuh") set during the Cultural Revolution, two young boys gorge over forbidden novels from this French author's series The Human Comedy.
answers_formatted: The Cultural Revolution [or Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution or Wénhuà dàgémìng; prompt on 1960s or 1970s]
Honoré de Balzac [accept Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress]
acceptable: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the stream function in fluid mechanics:
answers: Laplacian [or Laplace operator or del squared; do not accept or prompt on "del"]
parts: The stream function is constant along streamlines, which run tangent to this vector quantity. By Bernoulli's principle, holding potential energy constant and increasing pressure decreases this quantity.
The stream function can only be defined for two-dimensional flows with this property, meaning that the fluid's density remains constant.
The vorticity, which describes the rotation of a fluid, can be calculated as negative this operation applied to the stream function.
answers_formatted: Laplacian [or Laplace operator or del squared; do not accept or prompt on "del"]

bonuses.leadin: A secularist and Guardian columnist from this family named Polly wrote Hard Work, a book examining low-paid jobs in Britain. For 10 points each:
answers: Toynbee [accept Polly Toynbee, or Arnold Toynbee, or Toynbee Hall]
Hadrian [or Caesar Traianus Hadrianus; accept Hadrian's Wall]
parts: Name this British family. It produced an economic historian who lent his name to a "hall" which was London's first settlement house for the poor, and which inspired the work of Jane Addams in America.
Another member of the family, Arnold J. Toynbee, is best-known for this 12-volume work which traces the rise and fall of 19 civilizations and examines several "aborted" and "arrested" ones.

Yet another family member, Jocelyn Toynbee, was Britain's leading historian of Roman art; her first work focuses on sculpture from the era of this emperor, who built a wall from Solway Firth to the North Sea.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of a 1974 movie previously worked with Lieutenant Lou Escobar in this place. For 10 points each:
answers: Chinatown [or, more specifically, Los Angeles' Chinatown; prompt on Los Angeles]
parts: Name this place. At the end of that movie, detective Jake Gittes, played by Jack Nicholson, fails to prevent the police from killing Evelyn Mulwray in this place.
Chinatown is an example of the "neo-" variety of this kind of film. This term, which is usually applied to gritty crime dramas, comes from the fact that they were often shot in black-and-white.
This composer composed the score for Chinatown in only ten days. This man used the "blaster beam" to voice the character of V'Ger in his iconic score for Star Trek: The Motion Picture.
answers_formatted: Chinatown [or or, more specifically, Los Angeles' Chinatown; prompt on Los Angeles]
acceptable: or, more specifically, Los Angeles' Chinatown

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name these English words which come from plays:
answers: malapropism [prompt on Mrs. Malaprop] (She is from The Rivals.)
lonely [accept lonely dragon or "I Wandered Lonely As a Cloud"]
parts: The name of these beings, which comes from a Czech word for "serf" or "laborer," was introduced to English by a Karel Čapek play in which Rossum invents them.
This word is named for a character who speaks of such concepts as "the very pineapple of politeness" and "an allegory on the banks of the Nile" to people such as Captain Absolute.

The first use of this adjective is in a Shakespeare speech in which Coriolanus describes himself as this sort of "dragon" in a fen. This adjective appears in the first line of a poem about objects which are "Continuous as the stars that shine / And twinkle on the milky way".
answers_formatted: lonely [accept lonely dragon or I Wandered Lonely As a Cloud]
acceptable: I Wandered Lonely As a Cloud

bonuses.leadin: A group automorphism is inner if it's given by performing this operation. For 10 points each:
answers: conjugation [accept word forms like conjugate or conjugacy; accept complex conjugation]
symmetric groups [accept S sub n; prompt on Sn]
six [accept the symmetric group on six elements or equivalent phrasings, S6, or S sub 6]
parts: Name this operation that multiplies the elements of a group by an element and its inverse on opposite sides. The same word indicates sending a complex number a plus b i to a minus b i.
Elements of these groups are conjugate if and only if they have the same cycle structure. These groups of order n consist of the various permutations of the n elements.
Symmetric groups have only inner automorphisms except the one on this many elements, which has an outer automorphism due to an exotic embedding of the symmetric group on one fewer element.
answers_formatted: conjugation [accept word forms like conjugate or conjugacy; accept complex conjugation]
six [accept the symmetric group on six elements or equivalent phrasings, S6, or S sub 6]

bonuses.leadin: During a riot at this university, students burned effigies of Jane Bassett Spilman and Elizabeth Zinser, who served just six days as President. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Washington D.C. university where students took part in the Deaf President Now protests. This university's football team invented the huddle.
This newspaper editor of the Argus and the Washington Globe donated land for Gallaudet University. This Kentucky-born politician was Postmaster General under Andrew Jackson.
In 2006, the Unity for Gallaudet Movement accused provost Jane Fernandes of being "not deaf enough" because she lacked fluency in this non-oral language.

bonuses.leadin: In the Aeneid, this goddess embodies rage and madness, or furor, which is often opposed by Aeneas's pietas. For 10 points each:
answers: Juno [accept Iūnō; accept Juno Regina, Juno Moneta, or Juno Lucina; prompt on Sospita; prompt on Hera]
Neptune [accept Neptunus or Neptunus Equester; prompt on Poseidon]
parts: What goddess indirectly causes the attempted burning of the Trojan ships? The epithet omnipotens is given to her and her husband, Jupiter.
After Jupiter sends a rainstorm to quench the flames, this deity swears to protect the Trojan fleet. In Book I of the Aeneid, this deity saves the Trojan fleet from Aeolus's ("EE-oh-lus'z") winds.
The price for Neptune's aid is the death of this character, who is Aeneas's helmsman. In Book VI, his shade tells Aeneas how he washed ashore near Valia, where he was killed and left unburied.
answers_formatted: Juno [accept Iūnō; accept Juno Regina, Juno Moneta, or Juno Lucina; prompt on Sospita; prompt on Hera]

bonuses.leadin: The south-westerly sea breeze which hits this state in the summer has been nicknamed the Fremantle Doctor. For 10 points each:
answers: Western Australia (Western Australia's capital is Perth.)
coral [accept Coral Coast] (The ecosystem is the Great Barrier Reef.)
parts: Name this state. The mild Mediterranean climate between the Darling Scarp and the Indian Ocean created an ideal spot for its capital city.
Western Australia's mild climate makes it great for beachgoers in a "coast" named after this animal. The largest ecosystem in the world created by this animal is off of Queensland's coast.

Unlike most of Western Australia, this northernmost region of that state has a savannah-like climate influenced by the Indo-Australian tropical monsoon. It shares its name with an African city which is home to the "Big Hole," supposedly the deepest hole excavated by humans.
metadata: The ecosystem is the Great Barrier Reef.

bonuses.leadin: The Laudesi ("lao-DEZ-ee") confraternity commissioned a Madonna by this artist in which six angels hold up the Virgin's chair. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Italian artist. Drawing on Vasari, Frederic Leighton ("LIGHT-un") misattributed a "celebrated Madonna" by this artist to Cimabue ("chee-MAH-boo-ay") in one of his paintings.
Duccio's Rucellai Madonna is currently held in this city's Uffizi ("oo-FEET-zee"), which were once the offices of its Medici family.

Duccio mainly worked in Siena, where he painted his version of this scene for the cathedral. Simone Martini painted the Virgin underneath a blue and red canopy surrounded by saints in his version of this scene, which has an Italian name.

bonuses.leadin: Organisms may employ the evolutionary strategies of either r or K selection. For 10 points each:
answers: population density [accept density-dependence; I guess prompt on population size]
parts: K-selecting organisms tend to have population sizes near this quantity, the maximum amount of individuals that can be sustained in a given environment.

Factors that are "dependent" on this quantity are thus generally more significant to K-selecting organisms than r-selecting ones. Logistic population growth occurs in a manner "dependent" on this quantity.
r-selecting organisms tend to follow this type of survivorship curve. These concave-up curves involve many individuals dying early in their lifespan, with a few survivors living for a long time.
answers_formatted: population density [accept density-dependence; I guess prompt on population size]

bonuses.leadin: James Mooney's study of this movement argued that the Mormon temple garment was the source of its sacred shirts, which were believed to repel bullets. For 10 points each:
answers: Ghost Dance [or Nanissáanah; accept Ghost Dance of 1890]
Morning Star [prompt on Venus; do not accept or prompt on "Evening Star"; do not accept or prompt on just "star(s)"; accept Morning Star ceremony]
parts: Name this 19th century millenarian movement that believed that the namesake ritual would expel settlers and revive participants' ancestors.
The Ghost Dance held this celestial body to be the most sacred and used clothing with equal-armed crosses representing it. The Skidi Pawnee regularly sacrificed girls to this entity.
Ghost Dance leaders caused trances in dancers by waving fans made of these objects. A namesake law legalized Native Americans' religious use of these objects, such as in headdresses.
answers_formatted: Morning Star [prompt on Venus; do not accept or prompt on "Evening Star"; do not accept or prompt on "just "star"]

bonuses.leadin: Prior to its invasion during Operation Polo, Mir Osman Ali Khan ruled from this city. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city, which was the capital of a princely kingdom ruled by the Asaf Jahi dynasty. Its Salar Jung dynasty, whose rulers took the title of Nizam, founded a museum of curiosities in it.
Hyderabad's Golconda mines were once the world's only source of these objects, one of which known as the Koh-i-Noor was placed on the Peacock Throne.

The Nizams once paid tribute to this empire that dominated the Deccan Plateau. Founded by Shivaji, it overtook the Mughals as a regional power and fought three wars with the British in the late 1700s.

bonuses.leadin: An extremely popular set of three of these pieces were dedicated to Marie Pleyel. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this genre of the soft pieces collected in Frédéric Chopin's Opus 9. The best-known of that set of these pieces is the second, which is in E-flat major and 12/8 ("twelve-eight") time.
The Nocturne Op. 9, No. 2 makes heavy use of turns on this note, whose major key signature lacks both sharps and flats.

Near its end, the Nocturne Op. 9 No. 2 includes a passage marked by this term, indicating that the piece should quickly accelerate toward a climax. In fugues, this term indicates the start of an imitation of a subject before the subject is completed.

bonuses.leadin: This poem sums up its author's Tory views on politics as "For forms of government let fools contest / Whate'er is best administered is best". For 10 points each:
answers: the great chain of being [prompt on chain]
parts: Name this didactic poem which describes its central subject as "Plac'd on this isthmus of a middle state / A being darkly wise, and rudely great". It states that pride is found "in erring reason's spite".
An Essay on Man is by this British poet of the satirical epics The Rape of the Lock and The Dunciad.

An Essay on Man states that this concept "draws all to agree" and asks the reader whether it is "upheld by God, or Thee?" A book by Arthur Lovejoy examines the history of this medieval idea of a hierarchy of creation.

bonuses.leadin: Henry Whitehead popularized this man's ideas during an 1854 cholera epidemic. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man, who went door-to-door in St. Luke's parish to trace that outbreak to the Broad Street pump. He is considered to be one of the fathers of epidemiology.
The aforementioned 1854 cholera outbreak occurred in this city. A 1665-1666 plague that struck this city was coincident with a "Great Fire" in it.

Max von Pettenkofer downed a bouillon laced with cholera in order to prove the Miasma Theory to this scientist. This scientist's examination of cholera outbreaks in Calcutta and Alexandria helped him quell an 1892 cholera outbreak in Hamburg.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about figuring out which STONKS to buy:
answers: stock dividends [accept dividend discount model; prompt on cash flows]
WACC [or weighted average cost of capital; prompt on cost of capital or discount rate or interest rate or average interest rate; do not accept or prompt on "capital"]
parts: A common way of valuing stocks is by summing up the discounted value of these payments across the entire future time horizon, known as their namesake "discount model".

To figure out how to discount the dividends, you find a company with similar cash flow risk and compute this value. For a company with a given risk, this value represents the average expected return on investment for equity and debt holders.
Maybe you don't want to buy stonks at all, since you're in one of these down-trending markets named for an animal. They're contrasted with "bull markets".
answers_formatted: stock dividends [accept dividend discount model; prompt on cash flows]
WACC [or weighted average cost of capital; prompt on cost of capital or discount rate or interest rate or average interest rate; do not accept or prompt on "capital"]

bonuses.leadin: The attractive term in this model can be replaced with a 10th-power term to describe hydrogen bonding. For 10 points each:
answers: London dispersion forces (accept either underlined portion) [prompt on van der Waals forces]
parts: Name this model for the potential energy between two non-bonded atoms or molecules. It is sometimes called the "6-12" potential, referencing how its terms vary with distance.
The 6th-power, attractive term in the Lennard-Jones potential represents these intermolecular forces, which form between an instantaneous dipole and an induced dipole.
The strength of the London dispersion force between two non-identical molecules is proportional to the product of their polarizabilities times the harmonic mean of this quantity.

bonuses.leadin: A photograph by this person shows the medium Master Herrod surrounded by the spirits of three continents. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this photographer who accidentally invented spirit photography after a self-portrait he took had the silhouette of a girl in the background.
This man was one of the people who testified against Mumler after he was arrested as a fraud. One of this man's own hoaxes involved the Fiji Mermaid, which was half-monkey and half-fish.
To prove Mumler a fraud, Barnum created a photograph of himself with this person. Mumler had earlier taken a spirit photograph with this person's "ghost" standing behind his wife Mary Todd.

bonuses.leadin: This man is the subject of a biography by Peter Gay subtitled "A Life for Our Time". For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man whose official English biography was written by Ernest Jones, who became the first English practitioner of psychoanalysis, a discipline this man invented.

Critics of Gay and Jones's biographies of Freud have labeled them with this term, which refers to biographies of figures such as Catherine of Siena. Many medieval ones are collected in The Golden Legend.
With Stephen Marcus, this author compiled an abridged version of Jones's biography. His best-known essay collection, which includes "Freud and Literature", is titled The Liberal Imagination.
